validated_findings.original_title: Protocol fee controller can be set to zero leading to frozen fees
validated_findings.reasoning: setProtocolFeeController is strictly onlyOwner and can be called again to replace a zero address; no public caller can trigger it. Freezing requires the owner both sets zero and renounces ownership, a governance error rather than exploitable attack vector.
validated_findings.why_pattern_hunter_missed: Scenario assumes owner intentionally bricks controller and renounces; static analysis treats admin misuse as exploit.

validated_findings.original_title: Unchecked accumulation of protocol fees can overflow
validated_findings.reasoning: _updateProtocolFees adds protocol fees in unchecked context, but values are economically bounded by total token supply and per-swap fee math; reaching 2^256 overflow is physically impossible, so unchecked add is safe and gas-optimized.
protective_mechanisms: Economic upper bounds on fee accrual (uint256 token balances)
validated_findings.why_pattern_hunter_missed: Assumed unchecked arithmetic implies overflow risk without considering realistic bounds.

removed_findings.reason: Owner-gated, requires self-inflicted misconfiguration; no external exploit path
removed_findings.impact: Avoids chasing admin error as vulnerability

removed_findings.reason: Overflow impossible given bounded fee amounts and total token supply
removed_findings.impact: Prevents unnecessary mitigation for gas-optimized unchecked add

skip.why: No attacker path; owner can always reset controller until voluntary renounce
Overflow scenario unrealistic; economic bounds make it safe
